qas.question: What determination of the study of law was held to much debate?

answers.text: whether certain opinions of law were orthodox

qas.question: What is the Islamic term for issuing a legal opinion?
What type of matters are covered through Islamic law?

plausible_answers.text: whether certain opinions of law were orthodox

qas.question: What determination of the study of law was never scrutinized?
What is the non-Islamic term for issuing a legal opinion?

plausible_answers.text: civil as well as religious matters

qas.question: What type of matters are covered through non-Islamic law?
What is the opposite of ijtihad?

plausible_answers.text: the exertion of one's efforts to the utmost limit

qas.question: What isn't the translation of ijtihad?

context: Much of the study in the madrasah college centred on examining <a0_0><b4_0>whether certain opinions of law were orthodox<b4_0/><a0_0/>. This scholarly process of "determining orthodoxy began with a question which the Muslim layman, called in that capacity mustaftī, presented to a jurisconsult, called mufti, soliciting from him a response, called <a1_0><b5_0>fatwa<b5_0/><a1_0/>, a legal opinion (the religious law of Islam covers <a2_0><b6_0>civil as well as religious<a2_0/> matters<b6_0/>). The mufti (professor of legal opinions) took this question, studied it, researched it intensively in the sacred scriptures, in order to find a solution to it. This <a3_0>process of <b7_0>scholarly research<b7_0/><a3_0/> was called ijtihād, literally, <b8_0>the exertion of one's efforts to the utmost limit<b8_0/>."
